images.name: 20170722_091758.jpg
images.description: A very pretty pink flower which we believe to be an Arcado Pink Agastache flower. Some of them have started to redden, but a few have maintened the heavy pink colour.

images.name: 20170722_091811.jpg
images.description: Another picture of the previous flower.

images.name: 20170722_093916.jpg
images.description: Another pink flower which we have identified to be in the Nerine genus. The tip of the flower looks similar to the bluebell, as it curls down due to it's weight.

images.name: 20170722_094638.jpg
images.description: A spikey pink flower. This is the Silybum marianum, or more commonly known as a milk thistle. Luckily none of us touched it!

images.name: 20170722_101430.jpg
images.description: Two white flowers, possibly of the Bindweed genus. As you can see, there are small raindrops on them.

images.name: 20170722_103940.jpg
images.description: Some white yarrow weeds. Although quite pretty, they are still weeds, and very common in this area.

images.name: 20170722_114204.jpg
images.description: Some bluebells in a wood. This was the optimal time of year for bluebells to grow.

images.name: 20170722_114656.jpg
images.description: A roadside pink flower. This has been identified as the cosmo flower.

images.name: 20170723_080822.jpg
images.description: A mixture of low-lying shrubbery including; Holy bush, brambles as well as a type of long grass.

images.name: 20170723_110544.jpg
images.description: We identified this small pink flower with five petals as a dog rose, also known as Rosa canina which is from the Rosacae family. We found out that this species of flower grows in hedgerows and on woodland edges and flowers around July, this supports what we saw on the expedition.

images.name: 20170723_114522.jpg
images.description: This is a large patch of Oxeye Daisies (Leucanthemum vulgare) from the Asteraceae family, as well as a smaller patch of purple Plume thistles (Cirsium) from the family Asteraceae, these species commonly grow in meadows around the UK.

images.name: 20170723_135311.jpg
images.description: This tall pink flower is known commonly as Fireweed but the scientific name is Chamerion angustifolium which is part of the Willowherbs family. We noticed that this flower usually grows in groups together near bushes and on the edge of fields.

images.name: 20170724_113540.jpg
images.description: Another small shrub with little pink flowers and leaves which had a rough texture. In the background there is a large blackberry bush.

images.name: 20170723_114537.jpg
images.description: Some more Oxeye daisies mixed in amongst the long grass.

images.name: 20170723_091202.jpg
images.description: A group of fallen trees which have created a small clearing in the woodland.
Two different natural tree arches formed up of the branches of various separate plants. These linked together over the path to create a natural doorway.
Another fallen tree resting around a group of ferns and long grass.
images.name: 20170723_091637.jpg
20170723_092636.jpg
images.description: An interesting formation of natural wooden spikes possibly made from a weed which has dried and dried out to create a barbed wire look around the base of this tree.

images.name: 20170723_093842.jpg
images.description: A coniferous woodland made up of tall trees and many ferns covering the forest floor. Moss can also be seen on some of the trees.

images.name: 20170722_110246.jpg
images.description: A very scary root formation... we were very careful not to fall onto this!

images.name: 20170722_092351.jpg
images.description: A strange tree formation, which covers a hole in the ground. They are sturdy enough to be walked on, although we were not sure how they were formed.

We identified this tree to be a blackthorn/sloe tree which is also known as Prunus spinose of the Rosaceae family. This plant is native to the UK and changes very differently. The tree has small black/blue berries, this particular tree was found near the Weir Wood Reservoir.
images.name: 20170724_134204.jpg
20170722_145359.jpg
images.description: A row of Redwood trees – These huge trees are also known as Sequoioideae and are a subfamily of coniferous trees within the family Cupressaceae. The redwood species contains the largest and tallest in the world and can live for thousands of years. We believe the trees in this photo are of a more common smaller species of redwood.
A very old Oak tree which is covered which thick ivy, most of which is now dead and has dried out. Right – ghost of chess.

images.name: 20170722_103538.jpg
images.description: A beautiful picture of a pathway on a nice sunny day. We were lucky at this point to have a smooth pathway as opposed to a muddy track. In this picture there is also a mixed variety of trees including a cluster of Beech trees on the left.

images.name: 20170722_095244.jpg
images.description: The way the sunlight reflects off these leaves makes it look like there are holes in the trees! In reality, the leaves are those with a similar design to maple leaves.

images.name: 20170723_082953.jpg
images.description: A large bramble bush with blackberries located on the edge of a woodland. This species is also known as the Rubus fruticosus and is part of the Rosaceae family. This species is actually made up of over 300 microspecies which have been recognised in the UK which can be identified through leaf shape and plant.

This vast area of ferns on the edge of Ashdown forest is known as Heathland and consists of many different types of fern including Blechnum spicant and Dryopteris which are also found in other countries across the Globe.
images.name: 20170723_094540.jpg
20170723_091546.jpg
images.description: A small patch of moss on the side of a footpath. Mosses are leaf like complexes and are like mini forests which offer habitat for other plants and insects. The moss in the photo may be Mnium hornum which frequently covers large areas of woodland floor.

images.name: 20170723_094720.jpg
images.description: above

images.name: 20170723_114526.jpg
images.description: A large meadow of wildflowers or varying species including Oxeye Daisies, Plume thistles as well as a reddish-brown species of grass which was commonly seen throughout our expedition.

An interesting field of crops which we came across during day two of our expedition, we aren’t certain what this crop is but it looked dead even though there was a huge field of it… This was the only time we came across this crop.
images.name: 20170723_131324.jpg

images.description: We came across a small lake which had a large amount of lily pads growing as well as white water lilies, also known as Nymphaeaceae from the Nymphaeales Order. Of all the bodies of water we passed during our expedition this was the only one which contained water lilies.
images.name: 20170724_100655.jpg
20170724_100702.jpg
images.description: above
A huge field of wheat, which is the most commonly grown crop in the UK.
images.name: 20170724_101414.jpg
20170722_095250.jpg
images.description: Some ferns and stinging nettles after a lot of rain. It rained a lot on our expedition, so these pictures were not hard to come by.

images.name: 20170722_101016_Richtone(HDR).jpg
images.description: A long straight pathway which cuts through a mixed woodland.

images.name: 20170722_101356.jpg
images.description: Some very grey dead plants. We have identified these as stinging nettles.

images.name: 20170722_113956.jpg
images.description: The sun really lights up these leaves. There are also some ferns on the right-hand side.

images.name: 20170722_115427.jpg
images.description: Very strong wind made all this long grass move! Walking through the long grass was surprisingly difficult. Meadows like this were very common during our walks.

images.name: 20170722_115737.jpg
images.description: Some blackberries and some thorns. It was very tempting to stop for a snack here!

images.name: 20170722_132155.jpg
images.description: This clay ridge not only has trees growing out the side of it but also has a large amount of moss and a small amount of lichen on the centre rock, we think this is due to the large amount of moisture present in this area.

images.name: 20170722_091748.jpg
images.description: A very dark green bush. We have identified them as conifers, and the light hits the bottom in an interesting way.
